revision.comment: Robot - Moving category South Kesteven to [[:Category:South Kesteven District]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 28]].
revision.text:
{{redirect|A606|other uses|A-606 (disambiguation){{!}}A-606}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} The '''A606''' is an [[A roads in Great Britain|A road]] in [[England]] that starts in [[West Bridgford]] {{nowrap|({{coord|52.9274|-1.1299|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A606 road (northern end)}})}} and heads southeastwards through [[Leicestershire]] and the towns of [[Melton Mowbray]] and [[Oakham]], terminating at [[Stamford, Lincolnshire]] {{nowrap|({{coord|52.6528|-0.4836|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A606 road (southern end)}}),}} on the former Great North Road.
==History== The route in earlier times was a far more important route than it is today. It was the main road from Nottingham to London. The turnpike went from Nottingham via Melton and Oakham to [[Kettering]] (to join today's [[A6 road (England)|A6]]), and then on to London, run by the Nottingham, Melton and Kettering Turnpike Trust from 1758. The turnpike trusts were abolished in 1880, the year that the railway line to Melton opened. The trains would run until 1968.
==Route== ===Nottingham to Melton=== [[File:Edwalton - Melton Road - geograph.org.uk - 1215929.jpg|thumb|140px|right|Melton Road in [[Edwalton, Nottinghamshire|Edwalton]] ]] The road begins a few hundred yards south of Nottinghamshire County Hall<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2397196 |title=Nottinghamshire County Hall:: OS grid SK5837 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> (built in 1937), in [[West Bridgford]] in the district of [[Rushcliffe]], at the traffic lights junction of the [[A60 road|A60]] (for Loughborough) and the B679 (for [[Wilford]]). The section to Melton follows the former railway from Nottingham to Melton, now the [[Old Dalby Test Track]], and to the [[A46 road|A46]] junction is only a few hundred metres apart. The line then continued from Melton to Oakham, then on to Corby and Kettering, and was the fastest route to [[Nottingham railway station|Nottingham]] by train from [[St Pancras railway station|St Pancras]]. It followed the exact line of the former [[Turnpike trust|turnpike]].
It begins as ''Melton Road'', and passes two churches then crosses the former railway line to Melton, and the [[BP]] ''Melton Road Filling Station''. There is traffic lights at a crossroad for ''Valley Road'', to the left, and ''Boundary Road'', to the right (for Rushcliffe Leisure Centre and [[Rushcliffe School]]). In [[Edwalton, Nottinghamshire|Edwalton]], the road then crosses<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/983158 |title=Melton Road near Edwalton:: OS grid SK5934 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> the former railway, where a few hundred metres further south it is still accessible by train. To the right is Wheatcrofts garden centre<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/983166 |title=Wheatcrofts Garden Centre:: OS grid SK5934 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> (started by [[Harry Wheatcroft]]) and the road meets the A52 at a busy roundabout,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/983162 |title=Approach to the Ring Road roundabout:: OS grid SK5934 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> where the road exits to the east as a [[trunk road]].
[[File:A606 at Tollerton - geograph.org.uk - 1614764.jpg|thumb|140px|left|Entering [[Tollerton, Nottinghamshire|Tollerton]] from the low bridge]] There is a 14 ft 6 in low bridge<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1614753 |title=Only high vehicles allowed:: OS grid SK6034 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> (the former railway), so there is a turning point<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1614762 |title=High vehicle turnback (1):: OS grid SK5934 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> for high vehicles. For the next mile the road<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1614764 |title=A606 at Tollerton:: OS grid SK6034 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> is the parish boundary between [[Tollerton, Nottinghamshire|Tollerton]] to the left, and [[Plumtree, Nottinghamshire|Plumtree]], to the right. It passes Tollerton post office<ref>{{cite web|author=more nearby |url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2152046 |title=Tollerton Post Office:: OS grid SK6033 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2010-11-09 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> and there is traffic lights for ''Tollerton Lane'' (for [[Nottingham Airport]]), where there is the [[Total S.A.|TOTAL]] ''Lane End Garage''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/186205 |title=Tollerton Lane, near Nottingham:: OS grid SK6033 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> The road becomes the parish boundary between Plumtree and [[Normanton-on-the-Wolds]], to the left. The former A606 used to go through both villages before 1930. At the end of the joint bypass, there is a right turn for the [[British Geological Survey]]. It passes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/185849 |title=A607, Nottingham to Melton Mowbray road:: OS grid SK6331 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> through [[Stanton-on-the-Wolds]]. At the junction for [[Keyworth]], there is the [[Murco Petroleum Ltd|Murco]] ''Wolds Service Station''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/159626 |title=Petrol station at Stanton-on-the-Wolds:: OS grid SK6430 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> At a crossroads, there is access to [[Widmerpool]], to the right, and the former [[Widmerpool railway station]]. The road meets the dual-carriageway [[A46 road|A46]] at an interchange.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/102589 |title=Bridge Over A46(T):: OS grid SK6528 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2006-01-07 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> This point is the southern end of the A46 Newark to Widmerpool Improvement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/4403.aspx |title=Newark to Widmerpool |publisher=Highways.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref>
[[File:A606 on Broughton Hill - geograph.org.uk - 134450.jpg|thumb|140px|right|Broughton Hill]] At Hickling Pastures, it passes Turnpike Farm, and there is a left turn for [[Hickling, Nottinghamshire|Hickling]]. The road becomes more hilly, and it passes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/908313 |title=A606 Melton Road near Upper Broughton:: OS grid SK6826 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> through [[Upper Broughton]] and its ''Golden Fleece''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diningpubs.co.uk/pub_details.asp?id=704 |title=East Midlands |publisher=Dining Pubs |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325110133/http://www.diningpubs.co.uk/pub_details.asp?id=704 |archivedate=25 March 2012 }}</ref> Crossing the Dalby Brook, the road enters<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/908355 |title=A606 Melton Road enters Leicestershire:: OS grid SK6926 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> [[Leicestershire]] and the district of [[Melton (borough)|Melton]]. In [[Broughton and Old Dalby]], it passes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/908352 |title=A606 Main Road in Nether Broughton:: OS grid SK6925 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> through [[Nether Broughton]], and its ''Anchor Inn''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diningpubs.co.uk/pub_details.asp?id=702 |title=East Midlands |publisher=Dining Pubs |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325110140/http://www.diningpubs.co.uk/pub_details.asp?id=702 |archivedate=25 March 2012 }}</ref> and ''Red House''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-redhouse.co.uk |title=pub, hotel & restaurant |publisher=The Red House |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> The road is crossed by a pylon line,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/908361 |title=A606 Nottingham Road:: OS grid SK7025 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> and ascends Broughton Hill<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/908365 |title=A606 Nottingham Road towards Broughton Hill:: OS grid SK7024 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> where the road rises 80 metres in 0.5 km.
[[File:Ab Kettleby, The Sugar Loaf.jpg|thumb|140px|left|''Sugar Loaf'' in [[Ab Kettleby]] ]] On the top of the hill, there are crossroads, which is highest point of the road at 171 metres, for a former Roman road (''Six Hills Lane'') that follows<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/909350 |title=Road near Ab Kettleby:: OS grid SK7223 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> the northern ridge of the wolds, where the right turn is for [[Wartnaby]]. The road descends down a hill<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/909439 |title=The Sugar Loaf, Ab Kettleby:: OS grid SK7223 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> into [[Ab Kettleby]], the former home of [[Desert Orchid]], passing the ''Sugar Loaf'' on the left. The road descends down the side of a valley and up onto Potter Hill.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/142752 |title=Potter Hill near Melton Mowbray:: OS grid SK7322 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2006-03-26 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> At this point the road enters the parish of [[Melton Mowbray]] as ''Nottingham Road''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/68442 |title=Nottingham Road, Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire:: OS grid SK7420 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> It passes the [[Esso]] ''Brookside Service Station'' and the headquarters of [[East Midlands Councils]], and Melton Borough Council on the right. It meets the [[A607 road|A607]] and A6006 at traffic lights and crossroads. Previously the road went straight through the town centre, which is now pedestrianised as ''Nottingham Street''. The southbound road now follows the A607 to the east on ''Norman Way'', then follows ''Thorpe End'' and ''Sherrard Street'' to the west, in a convoluted route through the town centre. The northbound route follows ''Leicester Street'' then ''Wilton Road''. Both meet at an awkward junction at the ''Anne of Cleves'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.everards.co.uk/pubs/anne_of_cleves_6/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927083039/http://www.everards.co.uk/pubs/anne_of_cleves_6/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-09-27 |title=The Anne of Cleves, Melton Mowbray |publisher=Everards |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29 }}</ref> onto ''[[Burton Lazars|Burton]] Road''.
===Melton to Stamford=== [[File:Potter Hill near Melton Mowbray - geograph.org.uk - 142752.jpg|thumb|140px|right|Potter Hill, north-west of [[Melton Mowbray]] ]] The road passes [[Melton Mowbray railway station]], and crosses the [[Birmingham to Peterborough Line]] and the [[River Eye, Leicestershire|River Eye]]. The road climbs the side of the River Eye's valley out of Melton, passing the former [[King Edward VII School (Melton Mowbray)|King Edward VII School]]. In [[Burton and Dalby]] it passes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/779527 |title=A606 Burton Road towards Melton Mowbray:: OS grid SK7617 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> through [[Burton Lazars]], and St James church,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1353983 |title=St James Church Burton Lazars:: OS grid SK7616 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2009-06-14 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> and is crossed by the [[Jubilee Way]]. At crossroads<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/149121 |title=A606/Whissendine Road Junction:: OS grid SK7815 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> there is a left turn for [[Whissendine]], and a right turn for [[Little Dalby]]. In [[Somerby, Leicestershire|Somerby]] at the top of Leesthorpe Hill,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/772926 |title=A606 Oakham Road:: OS grid SK7814 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2008-04-21 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> there is the ''Leesthorpe Crossroads]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/144557 |title=Melton Mowbray to Oakham A606 from Leesthorpe Crossroads:: OS grid SK7913 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> with a right turn<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/772931 |title=turn |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2008-04-21 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> for [[Leesthorpe]] and [[Pickwell]]. The road climbs to the top of a hill, where it becomes the boundary<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/772990 |title=A606 Oakham Road enters Leicestershire:: OS grid SK8013 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2008-04-21 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> between Rutland<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/772987 |title=A606 Oakham Road enters Rutland:: OS grid SK8013 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2008-04-21 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> (to the left) and [[Leicestershire]] (to the right), reaching 160 metres at Green's Lodge. Rutland became independent in April 1997. Leaving the Rutland boundary, the road descends to reach Whissendine Brook, and there is a left turn for Whissendine, and a right turn for [[Cold Overton]] and Northfield Farm<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northfieldfarm.com |title=Northfield Farm Shop and Restaurant - Home |publisher=Northfieldfarm.com |date=2011-11-19 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> (both in Leicestershire).
In [[Langham, Rutland|Langham]] it ascends the side of Ranksborough Hill<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/149019 |title=Ranksborough Hill near Langham:: OS grid SK8211 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2006-04-09 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> (at 191 metres, the second highest in Rutland), to reach 166 metres. Descending down the hill, it passes a right turn for Ranksborough Hall,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ranksboroughhall.com |title=Park Homes, Leisure Homes | Ranksborough Hall Rutland |publisher=Ranksboroughhall.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> an activity centre. In Langham, there is an abrupt turn to the left and one to the right, where it meets a road<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/149059 |title=View towards Melton from Langham:: OS grid SK8410 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2006-04-09 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> from Cold Overton. [[Ruddles Brewery]] was based here before 1997 - the year Rutland finally became independent. As ''Oakham Road'' it meets a roundabout<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2050173 |title=Roundabout on the A606 - Langham end:: OS grid SK8410 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2010-09-04 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> for the bypass in [[Barleythorpe]]. The former route through Oakham is now the B640. The £11.6 million bypass opened<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/leicestershire/6249799.stm |title=Oakham bypass |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-01-10 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> on Wednesday 10 January 2007, with construction having started<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/leicestershire/4360112.stm |title=Oakham bypass starts |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-10-20 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> in October 2005. The contract had been awarded to [[Alfred McAlpine|Alfred McAlpine Civil Engineering]] in June 2003. The next roundabout<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2050285 |title=The A606 Oakham Bypass:: OS grid SK8510 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2010-09-04 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> is for the [[Lands' End]] clothing company. It crosses the [[Birmingham to Peterborough Line]], and there is a roundabout<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2050389 |title=A606 Burley Rd Roundabout:: OS grid SK8609 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2010-09-04 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> for the B668 (''[[Burley, Rutland|Burley]] Road''), close to a [[Midlands Co-operative Society|Midlands]] Co-op superstore.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1280705 |title=Oakham's new superstore under construction:: OS grid SK8609 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref>
[[File:The Danish Invader - geograph.org.uk - 213972.jpg|thumb|140px|right|''Danish Invader'' on Empingham Road - Stamford was one of the [[Five Boroughs of the Danelaw]].]]
The bypass is crossed by the [[Hereward Way]], and at the [[A6003 road|A6003]] roundabout<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2051965 |title=Stamford Road roundabout on the Oakham bypass:: OS grid SK8708 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2010-09-05 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> the A6003 leaves to the south for [[Uppingham]], and the A606 leaves to the left (east). From here to [[Barnsdale Gardens|Barnsdale]], the road is followed by the [[Viking Way]] and the Macmillan Way. There is a right turn for [[Hambleton, Rutland|Hambleton]] (and [[Hambleton Hall]]), which is the former route of the road. When [[Rutland Water]] was built, the A606 was diverted to the north. The road passes on the north shore of Rutland Water, and the southern edge of Burley Wood. In the parish of [[Whitwell, Rutland|Whitwell]], at Barnsdale crossroads,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2238301 |title=Barnsdale crossroads:: OS grid SK9009 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> there is a right turn for Barnsdale Hall Hotel<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barnsdalehotel.co.uk |title=Barnsdale Hall Hotel. Conference Venue, Wedding Venue, Rutland, Leicestershire |publisher=Barnsdalehotel.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> and Country Club, and Barnsdale Lodge.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barnsdale Lodge |url=http://www.barnsdalelodge.co.uk |title=Welcome to Barnsdale Lodge |publisher=Barnsdalelodge.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> The road passes through Whitwell, where it is crossed by the [[Viking Way]], and passes ''The Noel''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenoel.co.uk |title=the noel at whitwell :: good food, live music, private parties, wedding receptions and accommodation |publisher=Thenoel.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> (''Noel Arms''). The road reaches the end of [[Rutland Water]], the largest reservoir (by surface area) in the UK, owned by [[Anglian Water]], and passes through [[Empingham]], where it is crossed by the [[Rutland Round]]. It crosses the [[River Gwash]], and is crossed by the [[Hereward Way]]. At [[Tinwell]] it meets the [[A1 road (Great Britain)|A1]] at an interchange built in 1960. It enters [[Lincolnshire]], [[South Kesteven]], and [[Stamford, Lincolnshire|Stamford]] as ''Empingham Road'' losing its trunk road status, passing the [[Malcolm Sargent]] primary school (former Exeter [[secondary modern school]]), on the left, and the ''Danish Invader'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/213972 |title=The Danish Invader:: OS grid TF0107 :: Geograph Britain and Ireland - photograph every grid square! |publisher=Geograph.org.uk |date=2006-08-03 |accessdate=2012-01-29}}</ref> on the right. There is a right turn for ''Roman Bank'' (former [[Ermine Street]]) and it reaches its terminus at ''Scotgate'' - the former Great North Road (B1081).
==References== {{GeoGroupTemplate}} {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|A606 road (England)}} * [http://www.sabre-roads.org.uk/wiki/index.php?title=A606 SABRE] * [http://www.sabre-roads.org.uk/wiki/index.php?title=Nottinghamshire_Turnpikes Nottinghamshire Turnpikes]

revision.comment: /* Functional notation */
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=December 2017}} In [[mathematics]], '''abuse of notation''' occurs when an author uses a [[mathematical notation]] in a way that is not formally correct but that seems likely to simplify the exposition or suggest the correct [[intuition (knowledge)|intuition]] (while being unlikely to introduce errors or cause confusion). However, the concept of formal correctness depends on time and on the context. Therefore, many notations in mathematics are qualified as abuse of notation in some context and are formally correct in other contexts; as many notations were introduced a long time before any formalization of the theory in which they are used, the qualification of abuse of notation is strongly time dependent. Moreover, many abuses of notation may be made formally correct by improving the theory. ''Abuse of notation'' should be contrasted with ''misuse'' of notation, which should be avoided.
{{anchor|Abuse of language}} A related concept is '''abuse of language''' or '''abuse of terminology,''' when not notation but a ''term'' is misused. Abuse of language is an almost synonymous expression that is usually used for non-notational abuses. For example, while the word [[group representation|''representation'']] properly designates a [[group homomorphism]] from a [[Group theory|group]] ''G'' to [[General linear group|GL(''V'')]], where ''V'' is a [[vector space]], it is common to call ''V'' "a representation of ''G''". A common abuse of language consists in identifying two mathematical objects that are different but [[canonical isomorphism|canonically isomorphic]]. Examples include identifying a [[constant function]] and its value or identifying to <math>\mathbb R^3</math> the [[Euclidean space]] of dimension three equipped with a [[Cartesian coordinate system]].
==Examples== ===Structured mathematical objects=== Many [[mathematical object]]s consist of a [[set (mathematics)|set]], often called the underlying set, equipped with some additional structure, typically a [[mathematical operation]] or a [[topological space|topology]]. It is a common abuse of notation to use the same notation for the underlying set and the structured object. For example, <math>\Bbb Z</math> may denote the set of the [[integer]]s, the [[group (mathematics)|group]] of integers together with [[addition]], or the [[ring (mathematics)|ring]] of integers with addition and [[multiplication]]. In general, there is no problem with this, and avoiding such an abuse of notation would make mathematical texts pedantic and difficult to read. When this abuse of notation may be confusing, one may distinguish between these structures by denoting <math>(\Bbb Z, +)</math> the group of integers with addition, and <math>(\Bbb Z, +, \cdot)</math> the ring of integers.
Similarly, a [[topological space]] consists of a set {{math|''X''}} (the underlying set) and a topology <math>\mathcal{T},</math> which is characterized by a set of [[subset]]s of {{math|''X''}} (the [[open set]]s). Most frequently, one considers only one topology on {{math|''X''}}, and there is no problem to denote by {{math|''X''}} both the underlying set, and the pair consisting of {{math|''X''}} and its topology <math>\mathcal{T},</math> although they are different mathematical objects. Nevertheless, it occurs sometimes that two different topologies are considered simultaneously on the same set; for distinguishing the corresponding topological spaces, one must use notation such as <math>(X, \mathcal{T})</math> and <math>(X, \mathcal{T}').</math>
===Functional notation===
One encounters, in many textbooks, sentences such as "Let {{math|''f''(''x'')}} be a function ...". This is an abuse of notation, as the name of the function is {{mvar|f}}, and {{math|''f''(''x'')}} denotes normally the value of the function {{mvar|f}} for the element {{mvar|x}} of its domain. The correct phrase would be "Let {{mvar|f}} be a function of the variable {{mvar|x}} ..." or "Let {{math|''x'' ↦ ''f''(''x'')}} be a function ..." This abuse of notation is widely used, as it simplifies the formulation, and the systematic use of a correct notation quickly becomes pedantic.
A similar abuse of notation occurs in sentences such as "Let us consider the function {{math|''x''<sup>2</sup> + ''x'' + 1}}..." In fact {{math|''x''<sup>2</sup> + ''x'' + 1}} is not a function. The function is the operation that associates {{math|''x''<sup>2</sup> + ''x'' + 1}} to {{mvar|''x''}}, often denoted as {{math|''x'' ↦ ''x''<sup>2</sup> + ''x'' + 1}}. Nevertheless, this abuse of notation is widely used since it is generally not confusing.
===Equality vs. isomorphism===
Many mathematical structures are defined through a characterizing property (often a [[universal property]]). Once this desired property is defined, there may be various ways to construct the structure, and the corresponding results are formally different objects, but which have exactly the same properties – they are [[isomorphic]]. As there is no way to distinguish these isomorphic objects through their properties, it is standard to consider them as equal, even if this is formally wrong.
One example of this the [[Cartesian product]], which is often seen as associative: :<math>(E \times F) \times G = E \times (F \times G) = E \times F \times G</math>.
But this is not strictly true: if <math>x \in E</math>, <math>y \in F</math> and <math>z \in G</math>, the identity <math>((x, y), z) = (x, (y, z))</math> would imply that <math>(x, y) = x</math> and <math>z = (y, z)</math>, and so <math>((x, y), z) = (x, y, z)</math> would mean nothing.
This notion can be made rigorous in [[category theory]], using the idea of a [[natural isomorphism]].
Another example occurs in such statements as "there are two non-Abelian groups of order 8", which more strictly stated means "there are two isomorphism classes of non-Abelian groups of order 8".
===Equivalence classes=== Referring to an [[equivalence class]] of an [[equivalence relation]] by ''x'' instead of [''x''] is an abuse of notation. Formally, if a set ''X'' is [[partition of a set|partition]]ed by an equivalence relation ~, then for each ''x'' ∈ ''X'', the equivalence class {''y'' ∈ ''X'' | ''y'' ~ ''x''} is denoted [''x'']. But in practice, if the remainder of the discussion is focused on equivalence classes rather than individual elements of the underlying set, it is common to drop the square brackets in the discussion.
For example, in [[modular arithmetic]], a [[finite group]] of [[order (group theory)|order]] ''n'' can be formed by partitioning the integers via the equivalence relation ''x'' ~ ''y'' if and only if ''x'' ≡ ''y'' (mod ''n''). The elements of that group would then be [0], [1], …, [''n'' − 1], but in practice they are usually just denoted 0, 1, …, ''n'' − 1.
Another example is the space of (classes of) measurable functions over a [[measure space]], or classes of [[Lebesgue integral|Lebesgue integrable]] functions, where the equivalence relation is equality "[[almost everywhere]]".
==Subjectivity== The terms "abuse of language" and "abuse of notation" depend on context. Writing "''f'': ''A'' → ''B''" for a [[partial function]] from ''A'' to ''B'' is almost always an abuse of notation, but not in a [[category (mathematics)|category theoretic]] context, where ''f'' can be seen as a [[morphism]] in the category of sets and partial functions.
==See also== *[[Mathematical notation]]
==External links==
[[Category:Mathematical notation]] [[Category:Mathematical terminology]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=July 2009}}
[[File:Carey mask1.jpg|thumb|250px|Carey mask]] A '''Carey mask''' (named after the inventor, George Carey) is a [[focusing screen|focusing aid]] for [[telescopes|astronomical telescopes]]. The mask is in the form of a thin card or sheet that is placed over the front [[aperture]] of the telescope. There are four series of slits in the mask which form a [[diffraction]] pattern in the image plane.
In this example the two sets of slits on the left are angled at 12 degrees to each other. Those on the right are angled at 10 degrees to each other. Different telescope and imaging combinations may require slightly different angles.
The diffraction pattern caused by the left hand slits will be in the form of an 'X'. The right hand slits will also form an 'X' shape, but the lines forming the 'X' will cross at a narrower angle. When perfect focus is achieved the two 'X's will be superimposed and be perfectly symmetrical. Any slight error in focus will cause the 'X's to be offset, and this is very noticeable to the naked eye.
In the example images below, [[focus error]] is obvious in the first two images. The third image is very close to perfect focus as shown by the equal spacing between the elongated spikes on the left and the right.
[[File:Focussing.jpg|400px]]
A negative image can sometimes show the [[diffraction]] spikes more clearly.
[[File:Focussing neg.jpg|200px]]
The enlarged view below shows the left hand spikes to be slightly further apart than those on the right. This is an indication that the focus knob needs to be rotated slightly '''anti-clockwise'''. If the right hand spikes were further apart, a '''clockwise''' rotation would be needed. The mask should always be placed over the aperture with the same [[Orientation (geometry)|orientation]]. If the mask was rotated 180 degrees, then the focus knob directions would be reversed. The operator soon becomes familiar with the rotation directions needed for a given setup.
[[File:Detail of focus.jpg|200px]]
This indication of the direction of focus change needed removes much of the trial and error that can often be encountered when attempting [[astrophotography]].
==See also== {{Portal|Astronomy}} *[[Bahtinov mask]] *[[Hartmann mask]]
==References== * [http://www.geoastro.co.uk/careymask.htm Carey mask website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carey Mask}} [[Category:Telescopes]] [[Category:Optics]]
{{physics-stub}} {{astronomy-stub}}

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|date=October 2011}} {{refimprove|date=October 2011}} }}
The '''European Spatial Development Perspective''' (ESDP) is a document approved by the Informal Council of Ministers of Spatial Planning of [[European Commission]] in [[Potsdam]] in 1999. It is a legally non-binding document forming a policy framework with 60 policy options for all tiers of [[Administration (business)|administration]] with a planning responsibility. The [[strategic]] aim is to achieve a balanced and [[sustainable]] [[spatial development]] strategy.
== Key concepts == With the aim to provide an [[Regional integration|integrated]], multi-sectoral and indicative [[strategy]] for the [[spatial development]], the key ideas of ESDP are: * an integrated approach - Not just to look at specific sectors of development activity (e.g. environment, economic development, or transport), but to recognise that they all affect each other; * spatial development - a much wider view of the development, vital for integrative approach; * strategic aspects - interlinked actions to achieve balanced and sustainable territorial development; * indicative views - the responsibility lies with the developed regions and territories to implement the development principals.
== Spatial policy guidelines == # Development of a [[wikt:polycentric|polycentric]] and balanced urban system, and strengthening of the partnership between urban and rural areas, so as to create a new urban-rural relationship. # Promotion of integrated transport and communication concepts, which support the polycentric development of the EU territory, so that there is gradual progress towards parity of access to infrastructure and knowledge. # Wise management of the natural and cultural heritage, which will help conserve regional identities and cultural diversity in the face of globalisation.
== See also == * [[ESPRID]] * [[Interreg]]
==Further reading== * Andreas Faludi, Bas Waterhout: ''The making of the European spatial development perspective: no masterplan'', Routledge, 2002
== External links == *[http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/docoffic/official/reports/som_en.htm ESDP Report], [[Potsdam]], May 1999
[[Category:Urban planning by region]] [[Category:Urban economics]] [[Category:Regional science]] [[Category:European Commission projects]] [[Category:Geography of the European Union]]

revision.text:
[[File:Ardoise à fromage.jpg|thumb|Slate displaying fissility]] In geology, '''fissility''' is the ability or tendency of a rock to split along flat planes of weakness (“parting surfaces”)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Principles_of_North_American_Pre_Cambria.html?id=c0wPAAAAYAAJ|title=Principles of North American Pre-Cambrian Geology|last=Hise|first=Charles Richard Van|date=1896-01-01|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|language=en}}</ref>. These planes of weakness are oriented parallel to stratification in [[Sedimentary rock|sedimentary rocks]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VanQlSQdXRQC&pg=PA24&dq=fissility&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjVlor-kuvTAhUW92MKHT33BCAQ6AEITzAH#v=onepage&q=fissility&f=false|title=Structural Fabric in Deep Sea Drilling Project Cores from Forearcs|last=Moore|first=J. Casey|date=1986-01-01|publisher=Geological Society of America|isbn=9780813711669|language=en}}</ref>. Fissility is differentiated from scaly fabric in hand sample by the parting surfaces’ continuously parallel orientations to each other and to stratification. Fissility is distinguished from scaly fabric in thin section by the well-developed orientation of platy minerals such as [[mica]]. Fissility is the result of sedimentary or metamorphic processes.
Planes of weakness are developed in sedimentary rocks such as [[shale]] or [[mudstone]] by clay particles aligning during [[Compaction (geology)|compaction]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1ju0DAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=fissility&f=false|title=Sedimentary Petrology: An Introduction to the Origin of Sedimentary Rocks|last=Tucker|first=Maurice E.|date=2013-05-22|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=1118698908|language=en}}</ref>. Planes of weakness are developed in metamorphic rocks by the [[Recrystallization (geology)|recrystallization]] and growth of micaceous minerals<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ingram|first=Roy L.|date=1953-08-01|title=Fissility of Mudrocks|url=http://bulletin.geoscienceworld.org/content/64/8/869|journal=GSA Bulletin|language=en|volume=64|issue=8|pages=869–878|doi=10.1130/0016-7606(1953)64[869:FOM]2.0.CO;2|issn=0016-7606}}</ref>. A rock’s fissility can be degraded in numerous ways during the geologic process, including clay particles [[Flocculation|flocculating]] into a random fabric before compaction, [[bioturbation]] during compaction, and [[weathering]] during and after uplift. The effect of bioturbation has been documented well in shale cores sampled: past variable critical depths where burrowing organisms can no longer survive, shale fissility will become more pervasive and better defined.
Fissility is used by some geologists as the defining characteristic which separates mudstone (no fissility) from shale (fissile)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gcgp5oLFrZMC&dq=fissility&q=fissility#v=snippet&q=fissility&f=false|title=Sedimentology and Stratigraphy|last=Nichols|first=Gary|date=2013-04-30|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118687772|language=en}}</ref>. However, some professions, like [[Drilling engineering|drilling engineers]], continue to use the two terms interchangeably.
==See also== *[[Fabric (geology)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fissility (Geology)}} [[Category:Structural geology]]
{{geology-stub}}

page.title: Five hundred meter Aperture Spherical Telescope

revision.comment: Expand on staffing difficulties and move to its own section.
revision.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox telescope}} The '''Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope''' ('''FAST'''; {{zh|s=五百米口径球面射电望远镜}}), nicknamed '''Tianyan''' ({{lang|zh-Hans|天眼}}, lit. "Heavenly Eye" or "The Eye of Heaven") is a [[radio telescope]] located in the Dawodang depression ({{lang|zh-Hans|大窝凼洼地}}), a natural basin in [[Pingtang County]], [[Guizhou Province]], [[southwest China]].{{cite web |title=中国"天眼"能不能发现外星人？ |language=zh |trans-title=Can Chinese Tianyan find aliens? |date=22 February 2016 |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/world/2016-02/22/c_128741240.htm}} It consists of a fixed {{cvt|500|m}} diameter dish constructed in a natural depression in the landscape. It is the world's largest filled-aperture radio telescope,{{cite web | last = Brinks | first = Elias | title = China Opens the Aperture to the Cosmos | work = The Conversation | publisher = [[US News and World Report]] | date = 11 July 2016 | url = https://www.usnews.com/news/best-countries/articles/2016-07-11/china-builds-worlds-largest-radio-telescope | accessdate = 12 August 2016}} and the second-largest single-dish aperture after the sparsely-filled [[RATAN-600]] in Russia.{{cite conference |url=http://159.226.88.6/sinous2008/talks/21Apr/NanRendong.pdf |title=Project FAST — Five hundred meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope |last=Nan |first=Rendong |date=April 2008 |location=Beijing |conference=China-US Bilateral Workshop on Astronomy |conference-url=http://159.226.88.6/sinous2008/ |accessdate=4 July 2016 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21028165-300-china-starts-building-worlds-biggest-radio-telescope/ |title=China starts building world's biggest radio telescope |work=New Scientist |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=19 October 2015 }} It has a novel design, using an [[active surface]] made of metal panels that can be tilted by a computer to help change the focus to different areas of the sky.{{r|Normile}} The cabin containing the [[antenna feed|feed antenna]] suspended on cables above the dish is also moved using a digitally-controlled winch by the computer control system to steer the instrument to receive from different directions. Construction on the FAST project began in 2011 and it achieved [[First light (astronomy)|first light]] in September 2016.{{cite news |title=Xi commends launch of world's largest radio telescope in China |author=Xinhua |via=China Daily |date=25 September 2016 |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2016-09/25/content_26891108.htm}} It is currently undergoing testing and commissioning.{{cite web |url=http://fast.bao.ac.cn/en/FAST.html |title=FAST Homepage in English |accessdate=15 Jan 2017}} It observes at wavelengths of 10 cm to 4.3 m.{{r|Nan 2009|p=11}}{{Cite web | title = China builds super-sized radio telescope | first = Margaret |last = Harris | work = physicsworld.com | date = 27 January 2009 | accessdate = 20 October 2015 | url = http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/2009/jan/27/china-builds-super-sized-radio-telescope | quote = }} The telescope made its first discovery of two new [[Pulsar|pulsars]] in August 2017, barely one year after its first light.{{cite news |title=China's huge new FAST radio telescope discovers two new pulsars |first=Andrew |last=Jones |date=10 October 2017 |publisher=GBTimes |url=https://gbtimes.com/chinas-huge-new-fast-radio-telescope-discovers-two-new-pulsars}} The new pulsars PSR J1859-01 and PSR J1931-02, which are also referred to as FAST pulsar #1 and #2 (FP1 and FP2), were detected on 22 and 25 August and are 16,000 and 4,100 light years away, respectively. They were independently confirmed by the [[Parkes Observatory]] in Australia on 10 September. The telescope had discovered 44 new pulsars by September, 2018.{{cite web|last1=McGlaun|first1=Shane|title=Chinese FAST telescope finds multiple pulsars in early use|url=https://www.slashgear.com/chinese-fast-telescope-finds-multiple-pulsars-in-early-use-11503525/|website=slashgear|accessdate=11 October 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Andrew|title=China's FAST radio telescope detects three more pulsars|url=https://gbtimes.com/chinas-fast-radio-telescope-detects-three-more-pulsars?cat=chinese-martial-healing-arts|website=gbtimes|accessdate=14 December 2017}}{{cite news |title=China's FAST telescope identifies 44 pulsars |url=http://english.scio.gov.cn/chinaprojects/2018-09/12/content_63384697.htm |accessdate=12 September 2018 |work=scio.gov.cn}} ==History== [[File:FAST under construction, took from rim..jpg|left|thumb|upright|FAST under construction]] The telescope was first proposed in 1994. The project was approved by the [[National Development and Reform Commission]] (NDRC) in July 2007.{{r|IAU 2007|Normile}} A 65-person village was relocated from the valley to make room for the telescope{{r|Xinhua complete}} and an additional 9,110 people living within a 5 km radius of the telescope were relocated to create a radio-quiet area.{{Cite news |title=Xinhua Insight: Installation complete on world's largest radio telescope |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-07/03/c_135485389.htm |date=3 July 2016 |journal=[[Xinhua]]}}{{Cite news |title=China Telescope to Displace 9,000 Villagers in Hunt for Extraterrestrials |first=Edward |last=Wong |journal=New York Times |date=17 February 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/18/world/asia/china-fast-telescope-guizhou-relocation.html |quote=The report said officials were moving 2,029 families, a total of 9,110 people, who live within about three miles of the telescope in the area of Pingtang and Luodian Counties in the southwestern province of Guizhou. Depopulating the area will create "a sound electromagnetic wave environment" for the telescope, Xinhua said.}} About 500 families tried to sue the local government. Villagers accused the government of forced demolitions, unlawful detentions and not giving compensation.{{cite news|title=‘Thank the aliens’: Thousands displaced for China’s huge telescope |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/thank-aliens-thousands-displaced-chinas-huge-telescope-063846215.html |accessdate=2016-12-01 |agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |date=2016-12-01}} The Chinese government spent around $269 million in poverty relief funds and bank loans for the relocation of the local residents, while the construction of the telescope itself cost {{US$|180 million}}.{{cite news |title=The Quest For Life Beyond Earth: The World’s Largest Radio Telescope Just Went Online |first1=Cecille |last1=De Jesus |editor-first=Patrick |editor-last=Caughill |date=26 September 2016 |journal=Futurism |url=https://futurism.com/the-quest-for-life-beyond-earth-the-worlds-largest-radio-telescope-just-went-online/}} On 26 December 2008, a foundation laying ceremony was held on the construction site.{{cite web |url=http://gzrb.gog.com.cn/system/2008/12/27/010441147.shtml |title=中国科学院·贵州省共建国家重大科技基础设施500米口径球面射电望远镜（ＦＡＳＴ）项目奠基 |language=zh |trans-title= |publisher=Guizhou Daily |date=27 December 2008 |accessdate=28 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112030246/http://gzrb.gog.com.cn/system/2008/12/27/010441147.shtml |archivedate=12 January 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Construction started in March 2011,{{r|gm}}{{cite journal |arxiv=1105.3794 |title=The Five-Hundred-Meter Aperture Spherical Radio Telescope (FAST) Project |author1=Rendong Nan |author2=Di Li |author3=Chengjin Jin |author4=Qiming Wang |author5=Lichun Zhu |author6=Wenbai Zhu |author7=Haiyan Zhang |author8=Youling Yue |author9=Lei Qian |journal=International Journal of Modern Physics D |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=989–1024 |date=20 May 2011 |doi=10.1142/S0218271811019335|bibcode = 2011IJMPD..20..989N }} and the last panel was installed on the morning of 3 July 2016.{{r|Xinhua complete|arxiv}}{{cite news |title=China completes installation of world’s largest telescope |date=3 July 2016 |journal=The BRICS Post |url=http://thebricspost.com/china-completes-installation-of-worlds-largest-telescope/}}{{cite news |last=McKirdy |first=Euan |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/11/tech/china-fast-telescope/index.html |title=China looks to the stars with creation of world's largest radio telescope |work=CNN News |date=12 October 2015 |accessdate=19 October 2015 }} Originally budgeted for {{CNY|700 million|link=yes}},{{r|Nan 2009|p=49|}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gizmag.com/five-hundred-meter-aperture-spherical-radio-telescope/18930/ |title=China building world's biggest radio telescope |first=Darren |last=Quick |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=13 August 2012 |work=gizmag}} the final cost was {{CNY|1.2 billion}} ({{US$|180 million}}).{{r|Xinhua complete|wanted}} Significant difficulties encountered were the site's remote location and poor road access, and the need to add shielding to suppress [[radio-frequency interference]] (RFI) from the primary mirror actuators.{{r|Normile}} There are still ongoing problems with the failure rate of the primary mirror actuators.{{r|Normile}} Testing and commissioning began with first light on 25 September 2016.{{cite news |last=Morelle |first=Rebecca |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-37453933 |title=China's colossal radio telescope begins testing |work=BBC News |date=25 September 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 }} The first observations are being done without the active primary reflector, configuring it in a fixed shape and using the Earth's rotation to scan the sky.{{r|Normile}} Subsequent early science will take place at lower frequencies{{Cite conference |title=FAST low frequency pulsar survey |first1=Youling |last1=Yue |first2=Di |last2=Li |first3=Rendong |last3=Nan |arxiv= 1211.0748 |conference=Neutron Stars and Pulsars: Challenges and Opportunities after 80 years |conference-url=http://www.pulsarastronomy.net/IAUS291/ |date=20–31 August 2012 |doi=10.1017/S174392131300001X}} while the active surface is brought to its design accuracy;{{cite conference |title=The Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Radio Telescope Project and its Early Science Opportunities |first1=Di |last1=Li |first2=Rendong |last2=Nan |first3=Zhichen |last3=Pan |arxiv=1210.5785 |conference=Neutron Stars and Pulsars: Challenges and Opportunities after 80 years |conference-url=http://www.pulsarastronomy.net/IAUS291/ |date=20–31 August 2012 |doi=10.1017/S1743921312024015}} Video available at http://www.pulsarastronomy.net/IAUS291/video/DiLi/ longer wavelengths are less sensitive to errors in reflector shape. It will take three years to calibrate the various instruments so it can become fully operational.{{r|Morelle BBC}} Local government efforts to develop a tourist industry around the telescope are causing some concern among astronomers worried about nearby mobile telephones acting as sources of RFI.{{cite news |url= http://english.caixin.com/2016-09-26/100992047.html |title=Scientists Concerned About Plans to Make Telescope a Tourist Attraction |first1=Zhou |last1=Chen |first2=Wu |last2=Gang |journal=[[Caixin]] Online |accessdate=26 September 2016}} A projected 10 million tourists in 2017 will force officials to decide on the scientific mission versus the economic benefits of tourism.{{cite news|last1=Chen|first1=Stephen|title=How noisy Chinese tourists may be drowning out alien signals at the world’s biggest telescope|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2107893/how-noisy-chinese-tourists-may-be-drowning-out-alien-signals|accessdate=24 August 2017|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=24 August 2017}} ==Overview== FAST has a fixed primary reflector located in a natural [[sinkhole]] in the landscape ([[karst]]), focusing radio waves on a receiving antenna in a "feed cabin" suspended {{cvt|140|m}} above it. The reflector is made of perforated aluminium panels supported by a mesh of steel cables hanging from the rim. FAST's surface is made of 4450{{r|Xinhua complete}} triangular panels, {{cvt|11|m}} on a side,{{Cite news |title=China assembles world's largest telescope in Guizhou |date=24 July 2015 |url=http://www.china.org.cn/china/2015-07/24/content_36136455.htm |publisher=Xinhua |via=China.org.cn}} in the form of a [[geodesic dome]]. 2225 winches located underneath{{cite news |title=World’s largest radio telescope will search for dark matter, listen for aliens |first=Dennis |last=Normile |date=26 September 2016 |journal=Science News |url=http://www.sciencepubs.com/news/2016/09/world-s-largest-radio-telescope-will-search-dark-matter-listen-aliens |doi=10.1126/science.aah7346}} make it an [[Active optics|active surface]], pulling on joints between panels, deforming the flexible steel cable support into a [[parabolic antenna]] aligned with the desired sky direction.{{Cite report |first=R.L. II |last=Williams |title=Five-Hundred Meter Aperture Spherical Radio Telescope (FAST) Cable-Suspended Robot Model and Comparison with the Arecibo Observatory |url=http://www.ohio.edu/people/williar4/html/pdf/FAST.pdf |institution=Ohio University |date=July 2015}} Although this source contains wealth of detail, its [[WP:Identifying reliable sources|reliability]] is questionable. It describes in some detail (at the end of p. 4) the fact that FAST's dish is actually 519.6 m in diameter; papers published by the project scientists, who would presumably know, are explicit that the dish extends "up to a girder ring of exactly 500 m diameter". [[File:Bottom view from one of FAST's six support towers.jpg|One of six support towers for the feed cabin|thumb|left]] Above the reflector is a light-weight feed cabin moved by a [[cable robots|cable robot]] using winch [[servomechanism]]s on six support towers.{{r|arxiv|p=13}} The receiving antennas are mounted below this on a [[Stewart platform]] which provides fine position control and compensates for disturbances like wind motion.{{r|arxiv|p=13}} This produces a planned pointing precision of 8 [[arcseconds]].{{r|Nan 2009|p=24}}{{cite journal |title=The FAST telescope and its possible contribution to high precision astrometry |journal=International Astronomical Union |year=2007 |last=Jin |first=C. J. |last2=Nan |first2=R. D. |last3=Gan |first3=H. Q. |volume=248 |pages=178–181 |doi=10.1017/S1743921308018978 |url=https://journals.cambridge.org/download.php?file=/IAU/IAU3_S248/S1743921308018978a.pdf&code=0656ef736066004c9ea5e022a6df2e32 |format=PDF |accessdate=19 October 2015 |bibcode=2008IAUS..248..178J}}{{Rp|179}} [[File:Fast Illuminated aperture.png|thumb|upright=1.25|300 m illuminated aperture within 500 m dish|right]] The maximum [[zenith|zenith angle]] is 60 degree when the effective illuminated aperture is reduced to 200 m, while it is 26.4 degree when the effective illuminated aperture is 300 m without loss.{{cite journal |title=The optics of the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope |author=Jin Chengjin | display-authors=etal | journal=International Symposium on Antennas and Propagation |date=23 October 2013 |url=http://ap-s.ei.tuat.ac.jp/isapx/2013/pdf/339_2_0.pdf}}{{r|Nan 2009|p=13}} Although the reflector diameter is {{convert|500|m}}, only a circle of 300 m diameter is used (held in the correct parabolic shape and "illuminated" by the receiver) at any one time.{{r|arxiv|p=13}} Thus, the name is a misnomer: the [[aperture]] is not 500 m, nor is it spherical. Its working frequency range of 70 MHz to 3.0 [[GHz]],{{cite web |title=Receiver Systems |url=http://fast.bao.ac.cn/en/Receiver.html |website=FAST Home Page |publisher=National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences |accessdate=28 June 2014}} with the upper limit set by the precision with which the primary can approximate a parabola. It could be improved slightly, but the size of the triangular segments limits the shortest wavelength which can be received. This range is covered by nine receivers under the feed cabin,{{r|Nan 2009|p=30}} with the 1.23–1.53 GHz band around the [[hydrogen line]] using a [[Centered hexagonal number|19-beam]] receiver built by the [[CSIRO]] as part of the [[Australian-China Consortium for Astrophysical Research|ACAMAR]]{{cite web|title=Australia-ChinA ConsortiuM for Astrophysical Research (ACAMAR) |url=http://www.caastro.org/acamar |website=CAASTRO: ARC Centre of Excellence for All-sky Astrophysics |accessdate=1 October 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507125341/http://caastro.org/acamar |archivedate=7 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} collaboration between the [[Australian Academy of Science]] and the [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]].{{cite news |last1=Strom |first1=Marcus |title=CSIRO technology to be at the heart of the world's largest radio telescope in China |url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/sci-tech/csiro-technology-to-be-at-the-heart-of-the-worlds-largest-radio-telescope-in-china-20160505-gomt90.html |accessdate=7 May 2016 |work=Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Fairfax Media |date=6 May 2016}} The Next Generation Archive System (NGAS), developed by the International Center for Radio Astronomy (ICRAR) in Perth, Australia and the European Southern Observatory will store and maintain the large amount of data that it collects.{{Cite news|url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-blogs/astronomy-space-david-dickinson/fast-worlds-largest-radio-telescope-open/|title=FAST Radio Telescope Open for Business - Sky & Telescope|date=2016-09-27|newspaper=Sky & Telescope|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-10}} ==Science mission== The FAST website lists the following science objectives of the radio telescope:http://fast.bao.ac.cn/en/Science.html # Large scale [[neutral hydrogen]] survey # [[Pulsar]] observations # Leading the international [[very long baseline interferometry]] (VLBI) network # Detection of [[List of interstellar and circumstellar molecules|interstellar molecules]] # Detecting interstellar communication signals ([[Search for extraterrestrial intelligence]]) # [[Pulsar timing array]]s{{cite arxiv |title=The Role of FAST in Pulsar Timing Arrays |first1=G. |last1=Hobbs |first2=S. |last2=Dai |first3=R.N. |last3=Manchester |first4=R.M. |last4=Shannon |first5=M. |last5=Kerr |first6=K.J. |last6=Lee |first7=R. |last7=Xu |date=1 July 2014 |eprint=1407.0435 |class=astro-ph.IM }} The FAST telescope joined the [[Breakthrough Listen]] [[SETI]] project in October 2016 to search for intelligent extraterrestrial communications in the Universe.{{cite press release |url=http://astrobiology.com/2016/10/national-astronomical-observatories-of-china-breakthrough-initiatives-launch-global-collaboration-in.html |title=National Astronomical Observatories of China, Breakthrough Initiatives Launch Global Collaboration in Search for Intelligent life in the Universe |publisher=Breakthrough Initiatives |via=Astrobiology Web |date=12 October 2016 |accessdate=2016-10-14}} ==Staffing== The primary driving force behind the project{{r|Normile}} was [[Nan Rendong]] ({{lang|zh-Hans|南仁东}}), a researcher with the [[Chinese National Astronomical Observatory]], part of the [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]]. He held the positions of chief scientist{{r|CNN 2015}} and chief engineer{{r|Normile}} of the project. He passed away on 15 September 2017 in Boston due to lung cancer.{{cite news |url=http://www.chinanews.com/m/gn/2017/09-16/8332735.shtml |title=中国天眼"首席科学家南仁东病逝 享年72岁 |journal=China News Service |date=16 September 2017 |language=zh-Hans}} The Academy has been having difficulty finding staff for the telescope.{{cite news |title=Wanted: Researchers for China’s mega telescope to interpret signals from across the universe |date=31 October 2018 |first=Alice |last=Shen |journal=[[South China Morning Post]] |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/2171002/wanted-researchers-chinas-mega-telescope-interpret-signals-across}}{{cite news |title=China still having trouble staffing up its mega-telescope |first=Eric |last=Berger |date=5 November 2018 |journal=[[Ars Technica]] |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2018/11/china-still-having-trouble-staffing-up-its-mega-telescope/}} Its size requires a large staff, but they are having difficulty attracting astronomers to its remote location, making it unlikely that the telescope will operate at full capacity for some time.{{cite news |url=http://m.china.caixin.com/m/2016-09-25/100991650.html |date=25 September 2016 |title=院士：建世界最大射电望远镜不是为了发展旅游 |language=zh |journal=[[Caixin]] Online}} There is an [http://english.caixin.com/2016-09-26/100992047.html English-language version of the article], but that does not mention this issue，which is only described in the much longer and more detailed Chinese version. As China has few radio astronomers, they are soliciting staff internationally, but the pay offered is low, and many are worried about heavy-handed management for this high-profile project.{{r|wanted|helpwanted}} The Academy has likewise been searching for a qualified director of scientific operations for FAST since May 2017, but has not been able to fill the position.{{cite news |title=China is offering over a million dollars for a foreigner to run the world’s largest telescope, so why is nobody applying? |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2105278/china-offering-over-million-dollars-foreigner-run-worlds-largest |journal=[[South China Morning Post]] |date=3 August 2017 |first=Stephen |last=Chen}}{{r|wanted|helpwanted}} Although an offer of {{US$|1.2 million}} is widely quoted, this is primarily a one-time research grant, not salary or ongoing support.{{r|helpwanted}} ==Comparison with Arecibo Observatory== [[File:Comparison FAST Arecibo Observatory profiles.svg|thumb|upright=1.25|Comparison of the [[Arecibo Observatory]] (top) and FAST (bottom) dishes at the same scale]] The basic design of FAST is similar to the [[Arecibo Observatory]] radio telescope. Both are fixed primary reflectors installed in natural hollows, made of perforated aluminum panels with a movable receiver suspended above. And both have an effective aperture smaller than the physical size of the primary. There are, however, five significant differences in addition to the size.{{r|ohio}}{{Cite conference |title=The optics of the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope |conference=International Symposium on Antennas and Propagation |location=Nanjing |date=23 October 2013 |first1=Chengjin |last1=Jin |first2=Kai |last2=Zhu |first3=Jin |last3=Fan |first4=Hongfei |last4=Liu |first5=Yan |last5=Zhu |first6=Hengqian |last6=Gan |first7=Jinglong |last7=Yu |first8=Zhisheng |last8=Gao |first9=Yang |last9=Cao |first10=Yang |last10=Wu |institution=National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences |url=http://ap-s.ei.tuat.ac.jp/isapx/2013/pdf/339_2_0.pdf |conference-url=http://ap-s.ei.tuat.ac.jp/isapx/2013/}}{{cite journal |title=A novel design for a giant Arecibo-type spherical radio telescope with an active main reflector |first=Yuhai H. |last=Qiu |institution=Beijing Astronomical Observatory, The Chinese Academy of Sciences |journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] |volume=301 |issue=3 |pages=827–830 |date=11 December 1998 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-8711.1998.02067.x |url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/301/3/827.full.pdf}} First, Arecibo's dish is fixed in a spherical shape. Although it is also suspended from steel cables with supports underneath for fine-tuning the shape, they are manually operated and adjusted only for maintenance.{{r|ohio}} It has a fixed spherical shape and two additional reflectors suspended above to correct for the resultant [[spherical aberration]].{{Cite report |title=AOPAF: Arecibo Observatory Phased Array Feed |first=Germán |last=Cortés-Medellín |date=13 September 2010 |institution=National Astronomy and Ionosphere Center, Cornell University |url=https://www.naic.edu/~phil/hardware/byuPhasedAr/logs/Cortes%20AOPAF_short%20report%20Sept%202010-1.pdf}} Second, Arecibo's receiver platform is fixed in place. To support the greater weight of the additional reflectors, the primary support cables are static, with the only motorised portion being three hold-down winches which compensate for [[thermal expansion]].{{r|ohio|p=3}} The antennas are mounted on a rotating arm below the platform.{{r|ohio|p=4}} This smaller range of motion limits it to viewing objects within 19.7° of the zenith.{{Cite web |title=Arecibo: General Statistical Information on Antenna |url=https://www.naic.edu/~astro/general_info/basic.shtml |date=3 January 2005 |website=National Astronomy and Ionospheric Center |accessdate=5 July 2016}} Third, Arecibo can receive higher frequencies. The finite size of the triangular panels making up FAST's primary reflector limits the accuracy with which it can approximate a parabola, and thus the shortest wavelength it can focus. Arecibo's more rigid design allows it to maintain sharp focus down to 3 cm wavelength (10 GHz); FAST is limited to 10 cm (3 GHz). Improvements in position control of the secondary might be able to push that to 6 cm (5 GHz), but then the primary reflector becomes a hard limit. Fourth, the FAST dish is significantly deeper, contributing to a wider field of view. Although {{#expr:100*(500 / {{convert|1000|ft|m|5|disp=number}} - 1) round 0}}% larger in diameter, FAST's radius of curvature is {{cvt|300|m}},{{r|arxiv|p=3}} barely larger than Arecibo's {{cvt|870|ft|order=flip}},{{r|Arecibo}} so it forms a {{#expr:360/pi*asin(500/2/300) round 0}}° arc{{r|arxiv|p=4}} (vs. {{#expr:360/pi*asin(1000/2/870) round 0}}° for Arecibo). Although Arecibo's full aperture of {{cvt|1000|ft|m|0|order=flip}} can be used when observing objects at the [[zenith]], the effective aperture for more typical inclined observations is {{cvt|725|ft|m|order=flip}}.{{r|ohio|p=4}} (This is partially compensated for by Arecibo's location closer to the equator, so the Earth's rotation scans a larger fraction of the sky. Arecibo is located at 18.35° N latitude, while FAST is sited about 7.5° farther north, at about 25.80° N.) Fifth, Arecibo's larger secondary platform also houses several ''transmitters'', making it one of only two instruments in the world capable of [[radar astronomy]]. The NASA-funded Planetary Radar System allows Arecibo to study solid objects from Mercury to Saturn, and to perform very accurate [[orbit determination]] on [[near-earth object]]s, particularly [[potentially hazardous object]]s. Arecibo also includes several NSF funded radars for ionospheric studies. These powerful transmitters are too large and heavy for FAST's small receiver cabin, so it will not be able to participate in [[planetary defense]]. ==See also== * [[Chinese space program]] * [[Square Kilometre Array]] – a proposed 1 km2 telescope array in Australia and South Africa * [[KARST]] – a 1990s Chinese proposal to host the SKA ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal | title = Kilometer-square Area Radio Synthesis Telescope – KARST | first = R. | last = Nan | display-authors = etal | url = http://www.skatelescope.org/documents/SKA_CHN_CONCEPT_Karst_17062002.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | date = 16 June 2002 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061029202520/http://www.skatelescope.org/documents/SKA_CHN_CONCEPT_Karst_17062002.pdf | archivedate = 29 October 2006 | df = dmy-all }} * {{cite journal | title=The FAST telescope and its possible contribution to high precision astrometry | first=C. J. | last=Jin | first2=R. D. | last2 = Nan | first3 = H. Q. | last3 = Gan | journal = Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union | volume = 3 | issue = S248 |pages = 178–181 | date = October 2007 | url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/1F91AA86ABBD28527A4887B59562C38C/S1743921308018978a.pdf/fast_telescope_and_its_possible_contribution_to_high_precision_astrometry.pdf | doi = 10.1017/S1743921308018978 | doi-access = free | bibcode = 2008IAUS..248..178J }} * {{cite journal | title = The Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Radio Telescope (FAST) Project | arxiv = 1612.09372 | first1 = Di | last1 = Li | first2 = Zhichen | last2 = Pan | date = 30 December 2016 | doi=10.1002/2015RS005877 | volume=51 | journal=Radio Science | pages=1060–1064|bibcode = 2016RaSc...51.1060L }} ==External links== * [http://fast.bao.ac.cn/en/ Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope - website] * {{YouTube | a_7SBglFfik | Building the world's largest radio telescope – BBC News}} * {{YouTube | 7SRV3rnULO0 | FAST: The World's Largest Telescope – China Icons}} (25 September 2016) {{Radio astronomy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Five Hundred Meter Aperture Spherical Telescope}} [[Category:2016 establishments in China]] [[Category:Astronomical observatories in China]] [[Category:Cultural infrastructure completed in 2016]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Guizhou]] [[Category:Chinese telescopes]] [[Category:Qiannan Buyei and Miao Autonomous Prefecture]] [[Category:Radio telescopes]] [[Category:Search for extraterrestrial intelligence]]
